ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I greatly expanded my vocabulary and overall understanding and ability to communicate in ASL. I also learned more about deaf culture and the deaf community.

I really learned a lot about the language. The class was really well taught, so I felt like I had a very strong understanding of the basics of the language and a pretty good ability to use it at a basic level
An introductory understanding of how ASL functions as a language and of the culture that it is tied to.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I love how active the class was. There was always a variety of exercises and games. One thing is there were a couple of weeks when we did the same greeting and signing our name after we had all practiced it for weeks before and it became a little too repetitive.

The teachers were amazing! The way this class was taught was very engaging and having the opportunity to go to tables was great extra practice. The service projects were also a highlight that allowed us to get engaged with the Deaf culture a lot more deeply, which I am not sure we would have as much without the project. That is something very special about this program
I personally would have liked for it to be at a faster pace.

Having asynchronous class on Fridays to allow us time to work on our service projects and participate in other Deaf community events really enriched my learning. It also lessened the pressure that is often associated with language courses and made it more fun and easier for me to engage with the material. One weakness of this course is the fact that the homework is more of a suggestion since it is never graded or checked for completion. As an upperclassmen, I appreciated this and already know how to manage my time and hold myself accountable, but I know that first-years and sophomores may struggle more with that and lose that aspect of learning / practice.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this class. The new folks running and teaching in ASL are so kind and such wonderful educators.

Yes! Please take this course! The professors are amazing and really care about you doing well and understanding the language and material. It is also a very good way to learn about an entirely different culture that I think is special and very important to be aware of

Absolutely!! I think this language course really encourages learning and immersion in the culture unlike some other language courses. I didn't feel pressure or anxiety like I have with my other language course in the past and this helped me feel more comfortable practicing and signing in class.
